questions.text: A 45-year-old healthy man with a history of small streaks of blood in his stools is being sent for a colonoscopy to screen for colon cancer. This type of prevention is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option B: Secondary

Explanation:

Levels of prevention

Definition

Primordial (Option A ruled out)
  • Prevention of establishment of risk factors.
  • It aims to discourage people from adopting harmful habits.

Primary (Option C ruled out)

 
  • Prevention of onset of disease in a high-risk group/individual.
  • It aims to protect the health of those who are at risk.
  • Reduces the incidence of the disease.

Secondary (Option B)
  • Disease progression can be prevented at an early stage (Disease is reversible).
  • It aims to reduce the prevalence of the disease by early identification and prompt treatment of diseases, and it also prevents complications.

Tertiary (Option D ruled out)
  • Prevention or limitation of impairment and disability in a diseased patient who has developed complications due to the disease and the disease has become irreversible.
  • It aims to minimise a patient's suffering and maximise potential years of useful life.

questions.text: A pus swab has been sent for microbiological examination to your lab. After testing the sample how will you discard it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Yellow


Explanation:

  • Pus swabs are considered infectious waste and must be discarded in the appropriate biomedical waste bin.
  • According to BMW (Biomedical Waste) guidelines, highly infectious waste, including cultures, swabs, and dressings, must be discarded in yellow bins.
  • The yellow bin is meant for anatomical, pathological, and infectious waste that requires incineration or deep burial.
  • Other color-coded bins are used for different types of waste (e.g., sharps in white, plastics in red, glass in blue, general waste in black).

 

Biomedical Waste Disposal

Proper segregation and disposal of biomedical waste are essential to prevent infections and environmental contamination.

Blue (Option C): Incorrect because it is used for glass waste like vials and slides, not pus swabs.

 

Black (Option D): Incorrect because it is for general waste like office and household waste, not biohazardous materials.

questions.text: What is the standard unit for measuring the brightness of light emitted from a single point source?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Candela

Explanation:

  • Candela is the standard unit for measuring the brightness of light emitted from a single point source. It measures the intensity of light emitted in a particular direction.
  • It is one of the seven base units in the International System of Units (SI) and is used to describe the luminous intensity of light.

Photometry and Measurement of Light

  • Photometry is the branch of physics that deals with the measurement of visible light, considering human eye sensitivity. Light measurement is crucial in various applications, including illumination engineering, display technology, medical imaging, and astronomy.

questions.text: Which type of thermometer is employed to assess the low air velocity rather than the cooling efficiency of the air?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kata thermometer

Explanation:

  • Kata thermometer is specifically designed to measure low air velocity.
  • It is an alcohol-based thermometer that is heated before use, and the time taken for the temperature to drop from a higher set point to a lower set point is recorded.
  • This cooling time is then used to calculate air movement in still air environments, such as indoor ventilation studies and occupational health assessments.
  • Unlike other thermometers, it does not measure air temperature directly but rather the effect of air movement on heat loss.

Comparison of Thermometers

Thermometer

Purpose

Measures

Kata thermometer

Low air velocity

Rate of heat loss from a heated bulb

Globe thermometer

Radiant heat

Temperature considering radiation from surroundings

Wet globe thermometer

Thermal comfort index

Combination of air temperature, humidity, and radiant heat

Dial thermometer

General temperature

Direct air or surface temperature

 

 

Globe thermometer (Option B): A globe thermometer is used to measure the radiant heat in the environment, typically in the context of assessing the mean radiant temperature (MRT). It is not designed to assess air velocity.

Wet globe thermometer (Option C): A wet globe thermometer measures the cooling efficiency of the air, specifically by assessing both the ambient air temperature and the effect of humidity on heat loss from the body through evaporation. It is used in environmental health studies but focuses on cooling, not air velocity.

Dial thermometer (Option D): A dial thermometer is used to measure temperature, typically in laboratory settings, and does not assess air velocity or cooling efficiency.

questions.text: The Pathanamthitta district of Kerala was affected by floods and the government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. Which other chemical will be distributed along with it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Malathion

Explanation:

  • Doxycycline is given as prophylaxis against Leptospirosis, a common infection after floods due to contaminated water exposure.
  • Floods also increase mosquito breeding, leading to a rise in vector-borne diseases like malaria and dengue.
  • Malathion is an organophosphate insecticide used for mosquito control, making it the appropriate choice for distribution alongside doxycycline.
  • Other options (Zinc phosphide, Lindane, Paris green) are not relevant for mosquito control in flood conditions.

Chemicals Used in Public Health Disease Control

Chemical

Use

Relevance in Floods

Malathion

Mosquito control (insecticide)

Prevents malaria, dengue

Zinc phosphide

Rodenticide (kills rats)

Not used for mosquitoes

Lindane

Treats lice and scabies

Not relevant for floods

Paris green

Historical mosquito larvicide

Less commonly used today

 

Zinc phosphide (Option A): It is a rodenticide, but it is not used in flood situations alongside doxycycline.

Lindane (Option C): This is a pesticide used for external treatment of lice and scabies, not typically used for flood-related control.

Paris green (Option D): This is a pesticide primarily used for insect control in agriculture, not in flood disaster management.

questions.text: What are the most reliable indicators for regular monitoring of air pollution?

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles

  • Sulfur dioxide (SO2): SO2 is a gaseous air pollutant primarily emitted from the burning of fossil fuels, particularly those containing sulfur. It is a major contributor to acid rain formation and can have detrimental effects on human health, especially respiratory health.
  • Smoke: Smoke is a visible product of incomplete combustion, often associated with burning of biomass or fossil fuels. It consists of solid and liquid particles, such as ash and soot, which can cause respiratory problems and reduce air quality.
  • Suspended particles: Suspended particles, also known as particulate matter (PM), refer to a mixture of solid and liquid particles suspended in the air. These particles can originate from both natural and anthropogenic sources and have adverse effects on human health when inhaled.

 

Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter (Option B): While these are indeed important pollutants, the inclusion of lead as an indicator for routine monitoring of air pollution is not common practice.

Sulfur dioxide and carbon monoxide (Option C): While both SO2 and CO are air pollutants, they do not provide a comprehensive assessment of air quality on their own. Monitoring only these two pollutants would not capture the full range of pollutants that contribute to air pollution.

Carbon monoxide and hydrogen sulfide (Option D): While CO is an important pollutant emitted from combustion processes, hydrogen sulfide is not typically monitored as a routine indicator of air pollution.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) 0.5mm

Explanation:

  • The ideal thickness of lead aprons to prevent the technicians from radiation hazards is 0.5 mm.
  • Radiation exposure is hazardous (dose-dependent), ranging from acute radiation sickness up to genetic mutations, fetal anomalies and carcinogenesis.

RADIATION DOSE

BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS

<5 rad
  • No adverse effects

 

5-150 rad
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Mild haematological changes

  • Bone marrow failure (anaemia, infections, bleeding tendency - might require bone marrow transplantation)

questions.text: Mode of disposal of sewage ground water:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) All of the above

Explanation:

Sewage treatment plant:

  • Primary treatment involves screening, a grit chamber, and a plain sedimentation tank.
    • The process is anaerobic digestion.
  • Secondary treatment involves either the trickling filter or the activated sludge process.
    • The process involves aerobic oxidation
    • The activated sludge process is an easier method as it requires less process and involves an aeration tank.
    • Trickling filter is a biological filter that uses microorganisms to remove organic matter and nitrogen from wastewater .
  • Sedimentation tank is stage three of sewage treatment.

 

Other methods: Sea outfall, river outfall, land treatment. sewage farming, oxidation ponds, oxidation ditches

questions.text: An elderly man presents with leg deformities and skeletal abnormalities. On examination, he is using crutches and has visible bowing of the legs. It is also noted that several other villagers exhibit similar symptoms. Considering the cluster of cases in the same geographic area, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the investigation?

choices.text: Collect and analyze water samples for fluoride content

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Collect and analyze water samples for fluoride content

Explanation:

  • A cluster of similar skeletal deformities in people from the same village suggests an environmental cause rather than an individual nutritional or endocrine disorder. Endemic skeletal fluorosis from high fluoride levels in drinking water causes bowing of legs, bone pain, and deformities. Therefore, the most logical next step is testing the local water supply for fluoride concentration.

Endemic fluorosis:

  • Caused by long-term ingestion of water with fluoride >1.5 mg/L.
  • Early signs: joint stiffness, dental fluorosis.
  • Late signs: bony overgrowths, deformities, restricted movements.
  • Prevention: defluoridation of water, alternative safe water sources.

Check serum vitamin D levels (Option A): Could detect rickets/osteomalacia, but wouldn’t explain a cluster in the same area.

Measure serum calcium levels (Option B): Useful for metabolic bone diseases, but not the primary step in an environmental cluster investigation.

Perform parathyroid hormone (PTH) assay (Option C): For hyper/hypoparathyroidism; not first-line in a suspected environmental outbreak.

questions.text: What does the Langelier Saturation Index (LSI) primarily indicate in water quality management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Water balance: scaling vs corrosion

Explanation:

  • The Langelier Saturation Index (LSI) is used to determine whether water will deposit calcium carbonate (scaling) or dissolve it (corrosion). A positive LSI means the water tends to deposit scale, while a negative LSI means it is likely to be corrosive.

LSI = (pH of water) – (pH at which water is saturated with calcium carbonate).

  • Positive LSI → Scaling tendency (CaCO₃ precipitation).
  • Negative LSI → Corrosion tendency (CaCO₃ dissolution).
  • Zero LSI → Water is in equilibrium (balanced).

Used in water treatment plants and industrial systems to maintain pipeline and equipment integrity.

Total dissolved solids in water (Option B): Measured separately; not the purpose of LSI.

Hardness of water only (Option C): LSI considers hardness along with pH, alkalinity, and temperature.

Presence of biological contaminants (Option D): Biological quality is assessed by microbiological tests, not LSI.

questions.text: During a Health Mela organized by a medical college, the Nalgonda technique for water purification was demonstrated. Which two chemicals are used in this technique?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Alum and Lime

Explanation:

  • The Nalgonda technique is a simple, cost-effective, and scalable method for defluoridation of drinking water, developed by the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI), Nagpur.
  • It uses alum (aluminum sulfate) as a coagulant to flocculate and settle suspended impurities and lime to adjust the pH, enhance coagulation, and facilitate precipitation of fluorides.
  • This method is widely used in rural and community settings due to its low cost and ease of implementation.
  • In full-scale defluoridation, LAB (Lime, Alum, Bleaching powder) is added for combined purification and disinfection.

questions.text: A 20-year-old resident of Andhra Pradesh presents with outward bending of the lower limbs and signs of osteoporosis. His diet mainly consists of rice and jowar roti. What should not be done in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Provision of running surface water for drinking
Add lime and alum to drinking water

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fluoride supplementation:

Explanation:

  • The presentation — outward bending of limbs (genu valgum/varum), osteoporosis, and location in a fluorosis-endemic region — is consistent with skeletal fluorosis caused by chronic ingestion of high-fluoride water.
    • Fluoride supplementation in such cases is contraindicated because it would worsen bone and joint deformities by further increasing bone fluoride content.
    • Management focuses on reducing fluoride exposure, improving nutrition (especially calcium and vitamin D), and providing safe water.
  • Provision of running water (Option A), changing water source (Option B), and adding lime and alum (Option D) help reduce contaminants and improve water quality.

questions.text: Which of the following is the vector responsible for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Mite

  • The vector responsible for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is the Trombiculid mite, specifically the larval stage.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not responsible for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi.

questions.text: A student went on a trip to Jaisalmer, where the temp was 40 degrees, and relative humidity was 20%. What will the mechanism of heat loss be?
questions.solution:
• At high temperatures (40°C), radiation and conduction contribute less to heat loss since the surrounding environment is also hot.
  • Relative humidity is low (20%), which allows for efficient evaporation of sweat from the skin.
  • Evaporation is the most effective cooling mechanism in dry and hot climates, as sweat evaporates quickly, carrying away body heat.
  • Radiation works best when the surrounding environment is cooler than the body, which is not the case here.
  • Conduction requires direct contact with a cooler surface, which is not significant in this scenario.

Mechanisms of Heat Loss in the Human Body

The body regulates temperature through four primary heat loss mechanisms:

Mechanism

Description

Effectiveness in a Hot, Dry Climate

Evaporation

Heat loss through sweat evaporation

Most effective (low humidity allows efficient sweat evaporation)

Radiation

Emission of infrared heat waves to cooler surroundings

Less effective (ambient temp is high, reducing heat gradient)

Conduction

Direct heat transfer through contact with a cooler object

Minimal (air and objects in the desert are also hot)

Convection

Heat transfer via air movement

Limited (unless there is strong wind aiding heat dissipation)

In hot and dry environments like Jaisalmer, evaporation is the dominant mechanism for heat loss, as sweat evaporates efficiently due to low humidity.

Radiation (Option B): Incorrect because radiative heat loss is minimal when ambient temperature is high (40°C).

 

Conduction with air (Option C): Incorrect because air is a poor conductor of heat, and in desert conditions, it is already warm.

 

Conduction with objects (Option D): Incorrect because objects like sand and rocks in Jaisalmer absorb heat and are usually hotter than the body.

questions.text: Rukmini is attending the village health nutrition and sanitation program day. How frequently is this conducted?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Every month

Explanation:

  • The Village Health Nutrition and Sanitation Day (VHND) is scheduled to take place once every month, preferably on Wednesdays. In cases where certain villages have been missed, the VHND can be organized on any other day within the same month to ensure uniformity.
  • The Anganwadi Center (AWC) is designated as the central location for hosting the VHND, serving as a hub for service provision under various health programs such as RCH-II and NHM.
  • During the VHND, community health workers like ASHAs and AWWs mobilize villagers, with a particular focus on women and children, to gather at the nearest AWC.
  • At the event, villagers have the opportunity to receive basic health services, and gain valuable information on preventive and promotive healthcare practices.

questions.text: What type of sanitation facilities should be provided for the soldiers returning from war?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Trench latrine

Explanation:

  • Trench latrine facilities serve as vital sanitation solutions, particularly in military environments.
  • These setups involve excavating elongated trenches in the ground, fortified with materials to prevent cave-ins, and equipped with seating or similar structures for soldier utilization. They offer a straightforward and efficient means of waste disposal, particularly suited for temporary or field conditions.

Key features of a basic trench latrine include:

  • Trench dimensions typically measure 30 cm in width, with depths ranging from 90 to 150 cm, and lengths spanning 3 to 3.5 meters. Such specifications are designed to accommodate approximately 100 individuals efficiently.
  • To uphold privacy and comfort, separate trench latrines are designated for male and female soldiers.
  • Users are instructed to cover their waste with soil after each use, ensuring the maintenance of hygiene and sanitation standards within the facility.

Incorrect Options:

Pit method (Option A):

  • The pit method involves digging a hole or pit in the ground for waste disposal. While similar to trench latrines, pit latrines typically have deeper holes and may not be as suitable for military settings due to the need for frequent relocation and potential health hazards.

Dumping method (Option B):

  • The dumping method typically refers to the disposal of waste in designated areas, such as waste disposal sites or landfills. This method may not be appropriate for soldiers returning from war, as it lacks privacy and sanitation measures.

Acqua privy (Option D):

  • An acqua privy is a type of water-based toilet system that uses water to flush waste away. While common in civilian settings, acqua privies may not be practical or feasible for military deployments, especially in remote or austere environments.

questions.text: What is the recommended free residual chlorine level after chlorination of a well to ensure adequate disinfection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 0.5 ppm after 1 hour

Explanation:

  • According to standard guidelines for drinking water disinfection, a free residual chlorine level of greater than 0.5 mg/L (which is equivalent to 0.5 ppm) is required for effective disinfection.
  • This level should be maintained for a contact period of at least 1 hour to ensure that the water is adequately disinfected and safe for consumption.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D depict inadequate levels of residual chlorine for adequate disinfection.

questions.text: Orthotolidine test is used to determine

choices.text: Free and combined chlorine in water

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Free and combined chlorine in water

  • The orthotolidine-arsenite test (OTA) is used to determine the amount of free chlorine residual.
  • When orthotolidine reagent is added to water containing chlorine, a greenish-yellow colour will appear.

Nitrates (Option A): are typically measured using other specific methods, such as colorimetric tests involving reagents specific to nitrate detection.

Nitrites (Option B): can be detected using different tests, such as the Griess reagent test, which produces a different color change than the OTA test.

Ammonia (Option D): is typically measured using specific ammonia testing methods, such as the Nessler's reagent test or ion-selective electrodes, which produce distinct color changes or electrical signals in the presence of ammonia.

The OTA test:

  • is a colorimetric method commonly used to measure the concentration of free chlorine in water.
  • This test is often used to assess the effectiveness of water treatment processes, particularly those involving chlorination.
  • In the OTA test, orthotolidine reagent is added to a water sample containing free chlorine.
  • If free chlorine is present, a greenish-yellow color will appear, indicating the presence of free chlorine.
  • The intensity of the color change is proportional to the concentration of free chlorine in the water sample. This allows for a quantitative measurement of the chlorine residual.

questions.text: Air humidity and dew point temperature of the air is measured using which of the following instruments?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sling psychrometer

Explanation:

  • Air humidity is the moisture content of air.
  • It is measured using a sling psychrometer shown in the image below.

Air humidity measuring instruments

A. Hygrometer

B. Sling psychrometer

  • Wet and dry thermometers are mounted side by side

C. Assman psychrometer

  • Can be used even in strong sunshine

D. Dry and wet bulb hygrometer

  • Most widely used
  • Same readings in both (dry and wet) bulbs indicate 100 per cent saturation with moisture

Incorrect Options:

Kata thermometer (Option B): Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity and cooling power of air.

Barometer (Option C): A barometer is used to measure atmospheric pressure.

Dial thermometer (Option D): Dial thermometer is used to monitor temperatures in solutions or samples.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) A4-B1-C2-D3

Explanation:

  • Silicosis: Often occurs in workers exposed to silica dust in industries like mining and quarrying.

questions.text: Which international agency helps in construction of sanitary latrines( toilet building) in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - FORD:

  • The Ford Foundation has contributed significantly to various developmental projects in India, which includes the improvement of sanitation facilities. The foundation has been involved in initiatives aimed at improving living conditions, which includes the construction of sanitary latrines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - USAID: While USAID does provide developmental assistance globally, including India, their focus does not primarily involve the construction of sanitary latrines.

Option B - CURE: CURE International primarily focuses on providing medical care rather than working on sanitation projects.

Option C - Redcross: The Red Cross largely deals with emergency assistance and disaster relief, and does not primarily focus on building sanitary latrines.

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak?

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute
Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

Explanation:

  • Before collecting a sample from a regularly used tap, let the water flow for at least 2 minutes.
  • Hold the bottle at the base with one hand.
  • Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing.
  • Water from leaky taps is avoided.
  • Before collecting samples for taps that are not regularly used, the taps are sterilized by heating either with a blow lamp or a piece of cotton that is soaked in methylated spirit.

Sample for physical and chemical examination:

  • Collection glass: Winchester Quart bottles
  • Capacity: > 2L
  • Pre-collection: Rinse well thrice with water
  • Collection
  • Fill with water
  • Tight placement of stopper with a piece of cloth
  • Seal the string

Sample for bacteriological examination:

  • Collection glass: Clean bottle made of neutral glass
  • Capacity: 200-250 ml
  • If the sample is likely to have chlorine: 0.1 ml of sodium thiosulphate is added before cleaning

Transport and storage of sample:

  • Precaution: Keep the sample in ice till it's taken for analysis.
  • Analysis: Should be done within 48 hours of collection
  • Details
  • Date and time of collection
  • Source
  • Survey findings

 

Collect water from already leaking taps (Option A): is avoided as it can contaminate the sample if the water runs outside the tap and enters the bottle.

Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute (Option B): Before collecting a sample from a regularly used tap, the water flow is allowed for at least 2 minutes and not for 1 minute.

Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage (Option C): Keeping the water sample container close to the tap can cause the contaminants from the tap to pass into the water container.

questions.text: The ideal per capita space for students in a classroom should be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) >10 sq. ft.

Explanation:

  • The ideal per capita space for students in a classroom is generally recommended to be greater than 10 square feet per student. This allows enough room for each student to sit comfortably and engage in classroom activities without feeling cramped.
  • This standard ensures that classrooms are not overcrowded, promoting a better learning environment.

 

>5 sq. ft. (Option A): is incorrect because this amount of space would be too small for students, making the classroom uncomfortable and impractical for learning.

>15 sq. ft. (Option C): is incorrect because while this would be spacious, it is not always necessary for most classrooms. It could be suitable for larger or more specialized classrooms but is not typically required for all settings.

>20 sq. ft. (Option D): is incorrect because this is even more space than needed for a regular classroom. Though spacious, it may lead to inefficient use of space and resources in most educational settings.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the process that occurs in an oxidation pond?

choices.text: Aerobic during day, anaerobic during night
Anaerobic during day, aerobic during night

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aerobic during day, anaerobic during night

Explanation:

  • In oxidation ponds, aerobic conditions prevail during the day due to oxygen production by algae, while anaerobic conditions may develop at night due to the cessation of photosynthesis and continued oxygen consumption by microorganisms. This dynamic balance aids in the effective breakdown of organic matter.

 

Always aerobic (Option A): is incorrect because oxygen levels in oxidation ponds fluctuate, and anaerobic conditions can develop at night due to reduced photosynthesis.

Always anaerobic (Option B): is incorrect because during the day, algae in the pond produce oxygen through photosynthesis, creating aerobic conditions.

Anaerobic during day, aerobic during night (Option D): is incorrect because photosynthesis occurs during the day, promoting aerobic conditions, while anaerobic conditions typically develop at night.

questions.text: Sickness absenteeism of workers in the industry is used to evaluate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Health of the worker

Explanation:

  • Sickness absenteeism refers to workers being absent from work due to health-related issues.
  • It is a direct indicator of the health status of the worker and helps to evaluate patterns of illness and health hazards faced by workers in an industry.
  • This metric is commonly used in occupational health studies.

 

Health of the family (Option B): is incorrect because sickness absenteeism measures individual worker absenteeism and does not directly assess the health status of their family members.

Industrial environment (Option C): is incorrect because, although poor industrial environments may contribute to absenteeism, the metric specifically evaluates the health of the worker rather than environmental conditions.

Community health (Option D): is incorrect because absenteeism in an industrial setting is specific to workers and does not provide a comprehensive measure of overall community health.

questions.text: While measuring a patient's blood pressure at a primary health center, the sphygmomanometer accidentally fell and broke, resulting in spilled mercury on the ground. Which of the following is the most appropriate step to clean this spillage?

choices.text: Collect it by using a card on a sheet of paper and put the mercury into a jar
Collect it by sweeping it with a broom and throwing outside
Collect it by sweeping it and flush it in the toilet
Collect it by hand and then wash hands with water

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option A)

Explanation

This is the most appropriate and safest way to collect spilled mercury. Mercury forms small droplets, and using a card or a piece of stiff paper allows you to gently gather the mercury and place it in a sealed container (such as a jar). This method ensures that the mercury is contained safely, preventing further exposure to it or its vapor.

 

Collect it by sweeping it with a broom and throwing it outside (Option B): This is not a safe option. Sweeping the mercury with a broom would break the droplets into smaller pieces and increase the risk of inhaling toxic mercury vapors. Throwing it outside also poses a danger to the environment.

 

Collect it by sweeping it and flush it in the toilet (Option C): Flushing mercury down the toilet is hazardous. Mercury is toxic and can contaminate water supplies, causing environmental harm. It is also difficult to remove mercury from plumbing systems, leading to long-term pollution.

 

Collect it by hand and then wash hands with water (Option D): Handling mercury directly with hands is very dangerous. Mercury can be absorbed through the skin and is highly toxic. Additionally, washing hands with water after handling mercury is not effective, as mercury does not dissolve in water.

questions.text: Under which category of disaster management does the modification of building codes to construct earthquake-resistant buildings fall?
questions.solution:
Modifying building codes to construct earthquake-resistant buildings is a preventive measure taken to reduce the impact of potential disasters. Disaster mitigation involves steps to minimize risks and vulnerabilities, such as structural improvements and planning.

 

Disaster response (Option A): This refers to actions taken immediately after a disaster occurs, such as search and rescue, providing medical aid, and emergency relief. Modifying building codes does not fall under this category.

 

Disaster reconstruction (Option B): This involves rebuilding and restoring infrastructure and communities after a disaster has occurred. Building earthquake-resistant structures during reconstruction could be part of this phase but does not pertain to modifying codes as a proactive measure.

 

Disaster rehabilitation (Option C): Rehabilitation focuses on restoring normalcy and providing long-term support to affected individuals and communities, such as psychological care and restoring livelihoods. It does not include modifying building codes.

questions.text: Sandfly does not transmit:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: Option D: Sandfly does not transmit trench fever.

Trench fever is a bacterial infection caused by Bartonella quintana. It is typically transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus). Sandflies, on the other hand, are primarily known for transmitting other diseases, particularly those caused by protozoan parasites.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Kala azar (Visceral leishmaniasis): Sandflies, particularly species of the genus Phlebotomus in the Old World and Lutzomyia in the New World, are the primary vectors of Leishmania parasites, which cause kala azar or visceral leishmaniasis. 

Option B. Oriental sore (Cutaneous leishmaniasis): The disease is caused by various species of Leishmania parasites and is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected sandflies.

Option C. Oraya fever (Sandfly fever): Oraya fever, also known as sandfly fever. Sandflies, specifically species of the genus Phlebotomus and Sergentomyia, act as vectors for the transmission of these viruses to humans.

questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the minimum amount of land needed for the trench method to be applied in controlled tipping for a population of 10,000?
questions.solution:
Correct option: D. 1 acre

  • The correct option suggests that the trench method can be practiced for a population of 10,000 using approximately 1 acre of land.
  • This implies that the waste generation rate and trench size are such that a smaller land area is sufficient for waste disposal.
  • The trench method can be implemented on a smaller scale, making it a feasible option for the given population size.

 

Incorrect options:

Correct A. 4 acres: It indicates a larger land area than necessary, implying a waste generation rate or trench size that may be too high for the given population. 

Correct B. 5 acres: It implies an even higher waste generation rate or larger trench size, which may be excessive for a population of 10,000. 

Correct C. 2 acres: It suggests a relatively larger land area. This indicates a higher waste generation rate or larger trench size than necessary for a population of 10,000.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not lead to water hardness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Calcium carbonate

  • This compound does not contribute to water hardness directly.

Option B: Calcium sulphate- Calcium sulphate, also known as gypsum, is a common mineral that can dissolve in water, releasing calcium and sulphate ions.

Option C: Calcium bicarbonate- When carbon dioxide dissolves in water, it forms carbonic acid, which can react with calcium carbonate to produce calcium bicarbonate. This compound is soluble in water and contributes to water hardness.

Option D: Magnesium bicarbonate- Magnesium bicarbonate forms when magnesium ions react with bicarbonate ions in water.

questions.text: Mosquito having spotted wings is?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • Anopheles mosquitoes are known to have spotted wings. They are the primary vectors for transmitting malaria.

 

Incorrect option: 

Option B. Culex: Culex mosquitoes have uniformly colored wings.

Option C. Aedes: Aedes mosquitoes have dark-colored wings with prominent markings but not necessarily spots.

Option D. Mansonia: Mansonia mosquitoes have unspotted wings.
